facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 836 of 1963 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 836 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated January 4, 1962 of the Orissa High Court in S.A. No. 90 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated January 4. 1962 of the Orissa High Court in S.A. No. 90 of 1960.

facts.text: A suit was brought by eleven plaintiffs who are appellants including Dolai Molliko for a declaration that the plaintiffs were tenants with occupancy rights in the lands in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The brief facts necessary for present purposes are these. A suit was brought by eleven plaintiffs  who are appellants before us  including Dolai Molliko for a declaration that the plaintiffs were tenants with occupancy rights in the lands in dispute.

facts.text: The suit was resisted by the defendants who are respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was resisted by the defendants who are number respondents.

facts.text: The Munsif dismissed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The Munsif dismissed the suit.

facts.text: Plaintiffs appealed to the Subordinate Judge.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon there was an appeal by the plaintiffs.

facts.text: Dolai Molliko died in March 1958.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of that appeal, Dolai Molliko, appellant, died in March 1958.

facts.text: An application was made within time for bringing on record his heirs, the widow and a major son of the deceased.

anchor.surface_text: An application was made within time for bringing on record his heirs, and these heirs were two, namely, the widow and a major son of the deceased.

facts.text: No objection was made to this application and consequently the widow and the son of the deceased were substituted on record as heirs.

anchor.surface_text: No objection was made to this application and companysequently the widow and the son of the. deceased were substituted on record as heirs.

facts.text: The Subordinate Judge allowed the appeal and decreed the suit and gave the declaration prayed for by the plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge allowed the appeal and decreed the suit and gave the declaration prayed for by the plaintiffs.

facts.text: Defendants filed a second appeal to the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Then followed a second appeal to the High Court by the defendants-respondents.

facts.text: Dolai had left three other heirs: a minor son, a married daughter and an unmarried daughter besides the widow and the major son.

anchor.surface_text: When the appeal was pending in the High Court, it was discovered that Dolai had left three other heirs, namely, a minor son, a married daughter and an unmarried daughter besides the widow and the major son who had been brought on record as his heirs.

facts.text: Objection raised in High Court that as all heirs of Dolai not brought on record, the appeal before Subordinate Judge abated in toto.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently an objection was raised in the High Court on behalf of the present respondents that as all the heirs of the deceased Dolai had number been brought on record, the appeal before the Subordinate Judge had abated in toto.

facts.text: Orissa High Court accepted the contention and held that the appeal abated in toto.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accepted this companytention and held that as three heirs had been left out and as there companyld be numberquestion of want of knowledge of the existence of these heirs on the part of the widow and the major son who had applied for being brought on record, the appeal abated,

facts.text: High Court allowed the appeal, holding Subordinate Judge's appeal abated, restored Munsif's judgment dismissing the suit.

anchor.surface_text: In companyse- quence the appeal before the High Court was allowed holding that the appeal before the Subordinate Judge had abated and the judgment of the Munsif dismissing the suit was restored.

facts.text: Appellants obtained special leave from this Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellants obtained special leave from this Court and that is how the matter has companye before us.

facts.text: Respondents did not object in Subordinate Judge court that some heirs of Dolai left out.

anchor.surface_text: It may also be numbericed that the respondents themselves did number object in the companyrt of the Subordinate Judge that some of the heirs of deceased Dolai had been left out

facts.text: Supreme Court holds estate of Dolai sufficiently represented by widow and major son before Subordinate Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The only question therefore which falls for companysideration is whether the estate of Dolai deceased appellant was sufficiently represented before the Subordinate Judge by the widow and the major son.

facts.text: No fraud or collusion or circumstances indicating no fair trial or special case against absent heirs.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case there is numberquestion of any fraud or companylusion number is there anything to show that there had number been a fair or real trial, number can it be said that against the absent heir there was a special case which was number and companyld number be tried in the proceeding in his absence.

facts.text: Appeal before Subordinate Judge did not abate.

anchor.surface_text: we are of opinion that the estate of Dolai was fully represented by the heirs who had been brought on the record in the Subordinate Judges companyrt and that these heirs represented the absent heirs also who would be equally bound by the result, and there is numberreason to hold that the appeal before the Subordinate Judge had abated on that ground.

facts.text: Dolai's widow and major son applied for being brought on record.

anchor.surface_text: there is numberquestion of any diligent or bona fide enquiry for the deceased appellants heirs must be known to the heirs who applied for being brought on the record.

facts.text: Case proceeded in Subordinate Judge as if estate of Dolai fully represented.

anchor.surface_text: and the case proceeded there, as if the estate of Dolai deceased was represented in full by the heirs brought on record.

anchor.surface_text: It will be numbericed that there is one difference between the present case and the two cases on which reliance has been placed on behalf of the appellants. This is number a case where a plaintiff or an appellant applies for bringing the heirs of the deceased defendant or respondent on the record this is a case where one of the appellants died and his heirs have to be brought on record. In such a case there is numberquestion of any diligent or bona fide enquiry for the deceased appellants heirs must be known to the heirs who applied for being brought on the record.

arguments.claim: in Abdul Rahman, substitution of sons believing sole heirs prevents abatement despite other heirs under Mohammadan law

anchor.surface_text: In Abdul Rahman v. Shahab-ud- Din 1 , the appellant had died and only his sons were brought on the record and number his widow and daughters, though the appellant was a Mohanimadan. It was held that as the heirs who had applied for being brought on record as heirs and legal representatives of the deceased appellant bona fide believed that they were the sole heirs and legal representatives of the deceased, the appeal did number abate numberwithstanding that in Mohammadan law other persons would be companyheirs of the deceased.

arguments.claim: final substitution order prevents respondent from urging abatement due to other heirs left out

anchor.surface_text: In Mohd. Zafaryab Khan v. Abdul Razaq 2 , it was held that when by an order which has become final, a certain persons name has been brought on to the record of an appeal as the legal representative of the deceased appellant, it is number open to the respondent to urge that the appeal has abated because some other heirs have been left out.

arguments.claim: substitution of one heir represents entire estate; no abatement

anchor.surface_text: In Ram Charan v. Bansidhar 3 , the sole appellant had died leaving two daughters. One of his daughters was brought on record as his legal representative but number the other. It was held that the substitution of one of the daughters as legal representative of the deceased must be deemed to have been for the benefit of the entire inheritance which came into being on his death, and the entire estate, was represented by her and there was numberabatement of any part of it.

arguments.claim: failure to bring all heirs like widow is mere technical defect; no abatement

anchor.surface_text: In Babuie Shanti Devi v. Khodai Prasad Singh 1 , on the death of the plaintiff in a suit to enforce a mortgage his sons were brought on record but number his widow who had herself filed a petition stating that she was number in possession of the properties of the deceased plaintiff number did she desire any interest in the family properties, it was held that the failure to bring the widow on the record was a mere technical defect and the suit did number abate.

holdings.text: the estate of Dolai was fully represented by the heirs who had been brought on the record in the Subordinate Judges court and that these heirs represented the absent heirs also who would be equally bound by the result, and there is no reason to hold that the appeal before the Subordinate Judge had abated on that ground

anchor.surface_text: we are of opinion that the estate of Dolai was fully represented by the heirs who had been brought on the record in the Subordinate Judges court and that these heirs represented the absent heirs also who would be equally bound by the result, and there is no reason to hold that the appeal before the Subordinate Judge had abated on that ground.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Widow and major son as substituted heirs fully represented estate binding all heirs absent exceptions; no prior objection by respondents; case proceeded as fully represented; analogous precedents applied

holdings.text: unless there is fraud or collusion or there are other circumstances which indicate that there has not been a fair or real trial or that against the absent heir there was a special case which was not and could not be tried in the proceeding, there is no reason why the heirs who have applied for being brought on record should not be held to represent the entire estate including the interests of the heirs not brought on the record

anchor.surface_text: Even so we are of opinion that unless there is fraud or collusion or there are other circumstances which indicate that there has not been a fair or real trial or that against the absent heir there was a special case which was not and could not

holdings.reasoning_summary: Principle from defendant/respondent substitution cases (Daya Ram, Sulaiman) extended to appellant's heirs despite no bona fide enquiry needed; exceptions preserve fairness

holdings.text: In the present case there is no question of any fraud or collusion nor is there anything to show that there had not been a fair or real trial, nor can it be said that against the absent heir there was a special case which was not and could not be tried in the proceeding in his absence

anchor.surface_text: In the present case there is no question of any fraud or collusion nor is there anything to show that there had not been a fair or real trial, nor can it be said that against the absent heir there was a special case which was not and could not be tried in the proceeding in his absence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of fraud, collusion, unfair trial, or untriable special case against absent heirs

holdings.text: where a plaintiff or an appellant after diligent and bona fide enquiry ascertains who the legal representatives of a deceased defendant or respondent are and brings them on record within the time limited by law, there is no abatement of the suit or appeal, the impleaded legal representatives sufficiently represent the estate of the deceased

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmation of Daya Ram precedent as applicable analogously

anchor.surface_text: Daya Ram v. Shyam Sundari 1

precedents.cited_proposition: where a plaintiff or an appellant after diligent and bona fide enquiry ascertains who the legal representatives of a deceased defendant or respondent are and brings them on record within the time limited by law, there is no abatement of the suit or appeal, the impleaded legal representatives sufficiently represent the estate of the deceased and a decision obtained with them on record will bind not merely those impleaded but the entire estate including those not brought on record
precedents.cited_holding: the impleaded legal representatives sufficiently represent the estate of the deceased

precedents.citation: N. K. Mohd. Sulaiman Sahib v. N. C. Mohd. Ismail Saheb 1

precedents.case_name: N. K. Mohd. Sulaiman Sahib v. N. C. Mohd. Ismail Saheb
precedents.cited_proposition: if the plaintiff had proceeded bona fide and after due enquiry and under a belief that the persons who were sued were the only legal representatives, the whole estate would be bound including those heirs who were not arrayed as defendants
precedents.cited_holding: This Court followed the judgment in Daya Rams case and it was held that if the plaintiff had proceeded bona fide and after due enquiry...
